p.s: COP26 in Glasgow: A step in the right direction?
Why the arguments reached in Glasgow are reason for optimism, muted, but still optimism.
First of all, to evaluate the succeeding or failing of the COP26 we, as outsiders, need to adapt our expectations on its outcome.
We need to be aware of the fact that a conference like the one in Glasgow does not have the purpose to solve our problem with global warming but to build a foundation for measures.
As Ant√≥nio Guterres already states via Twitter, the actual starts at home in the respective countries.
Reason for a heated discourse was the phrasing in the agreement on the abolishing of coal.
Due to India and China's pressure it has been weakended to a phase down of coal production.
Critics say, this means it remains uncertain if the two states plan on ever completely abolishing coal or not.
However, there are more optimistic voices saying, the agreement is still a success as it is now globally clear that the coal era is over.
Additionally, it seems remarkable how this arrangement actually directly interferes with domestic state affairs.
As we all know, quick progress is essential when fighting climate change if we want to stay within reasonable limits of the destructive effects of it.
It is known that if we want to global warming to stay reversible, we need to reach Net Zero until the year 2050.
Clearly, we are not adapting quickly enough right now.
But, the COP26 shows us that we didn't make progress: Before Paris, we were warned of a heating of five to six degree.
Before Glasgow, this number has sunken to 2.7 degrees.
Although this still sounds terrifying, it is a sign that the COP26 in Glasgow indeed was a step forward.
